title: How to Relieve Canker Sore Pain

steps.title: See your physician if canker sores are a recurring problem for you.
steps.content: See your physician if canker sores are a recurring problem for you. If you have had canker sores more than once in the last 6 months, you should see your physician. If your child has a canker sore, talk to their doctor before using any home remedies. Most home remedies are considered safe for children over 2 years of age, but it is always best to speak to a doctor first. You should also see your physician if you have: [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source A large canker sore A fever associated with the canker sore Difficulty swallowing Sores that are spreading Sores that last more than 2 weeks Sores that are still painful after using home remedies

steps.title: Get treated for any underlying conditions.
steps.content: Get treated for any underlying conditions. Canker sores may be the result of an underlying condition, which will also require treatment. For example, if you have Crohn’s disease and have recurrent canker sores, then you would need to have treatment for the Crohn’s disease as well as for the canker sore. [3] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Other conditions that can lead to canker sores include celiac disease and Behcet's disease. [4] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Canker sores can also be triggered by stress, hormone imbalances, a weakened immune system, vitamin deficiencies, or mouth injuries. [5] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Allergies to certain foods, such as cheese, nuts, chocolate, coffee, or citrus fruits, may also be a factor. [6] X Trustworthy Source Cedars Sinai Hospital Website of one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Canker sores are not contagious or particularly dangerous, but they make eating and chewing more difficult. They can also be a sign of a more serious underlying problem.

steps.title: Request a test for vitamin deficiencies if you have frequent canker sores.
steps.content: Request a test for vitamin deficiencies if you have frequent canker sores. If you get canker sores a lot, it might mean you have a deficiency in vitamin B12 or iron. Ask your doctor to do a blood test to check for these deficiencies. [7] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If the tests show you have a deficiency, your doctor will probably recommend vitamin supplements. Let them know if you’re currently taking any other supplements or medications so you can avoid any harmful interactions.

steps.title: Ask your doctor about topical corticosteroids to treat your sores.
steps.content: Ask your doctor about topical corticosteroids to treat your sores. Steroid treatments can help reduce pain and inflammation from a canker sore. If over-the-counter pain medications and home remedies aren’t enough, ask your doctor if they can prescribe a steroid cream or paste that you can apply directly to the canker sore. [8] X Research source Some common steroid treatments for canker sores include 1% triamcinolone dental paste (Kenalog), 0.05% fluocinonide cream (Metosyn), and hydrocortisone (Corlan) 2.5 mg pellets.

steps.title: Talk to your doctor about Debacterol for severe pain.
steps.content: Talk to your doctor about Debacterol for severe pain. Another medication that can be used for canker sore pain is Debacterol. This topical treatment can provide rapid relief by cauterizing the canker sore. This medicine should only be applied by a trained doctor or dentist. [9] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Debacterol is available by prescription only.

steps.title: Apply dental wax to minimize irritation if you wear braces.
steps.content: Apply dental wax to minimize irritation if you wear braces. Some dental work, such as braces, may irritate a canker sore. If you have dental work that may be irritating the canker sore, ask your dentist for some dental wax to cover the dental work and minimize the irritation.

steps.title: See if viscous lidocaine is an option.
steps.content: See if viscous lidocaine is an option. You can apply viscous lidocaine directly to the canker sore for pain relief. Lidocaine is an anesthetic, which means that it will numb the pain. Keep in mind that lidocaine should not be swallowed or used more than 4 times per day. [10] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Never give lidocaine to a baby or a child under 3 years old unless your doctor instructs you to. If you’re pregnant or breastfeeding, tell your doctor before using lidocaine.

steps.title: Numb the pain with a benzocaine gel.
steps.content: Numb the pain with a benzocaine gel. Benzocaine gels contain a numbing medication that can provide quick relief from canker sore pain. These gels are available in most drug stores. Read the instructions and use the product as directed. [11] X Research source Examples of products that contain benzocaine include Anbesol, Kank-A, Orabase, and Zilactin-B. Some people can develop a rare blood disorder (methemoglobinemia) after using benzocaine, so don’t use more than the recommended amount. Children under the age of 2 are especially at risk, so don’t use these products to treat a baby or toddler unless your pediatrician recommends it. [12] X Trustworthy Source US Food and Drug Administration U.S. government agency responsible for promoting public health Go to source

steps.title: Try an over-the-counter pain reliever.
steps.content: Try an over-the-counter pain reliever. Try taking an over-the-counter pain reliever such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen to help you deal with pain from canker sores. Read and follow the dosage instructions and do not take more than the recommended amount. [13] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source If you are still in pain after taking one of these pain relievers, call your doctor.

steps.title: Use a hydrogen peroxide rinse to speed up healing.
steps.content: Use a hydrogen peroxide rinse to speed up healing. Hydrogen peroxide is an antiseptic that can help heal canker sores by killing bacteria and keeping the wound clean. Mix equal amounts of water and a 3% solution of hydrogen peroxide. You can either dab the mixture directly on the sore or swish it around in your mouth for a few minutes, then spit it out. [14] X Research source You can also get hydrogen peroxide rinses specifically designed to treat canker sores, such as Orajel Antiseptic Mouth Sore Rinse or Peroxyl. [15] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source As an added bonus, a hydrogen peroxide rinse can help whiten your teeth and keep your gums healthy! [16] X Research source

steps.title: Dab milk of magnesia on the sore for relief and protection.
steps.content: Dab milk of magnesia on the sore for relief and protection. Put a little milk of magnesia on a cotton swab and apply it directly to the canker sore 3-4 times a day. [17] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source This will soothe the sore and help minimize irritating acids in your mouth. You can buy milk of magnesia in most drugstores.

steps.title: Dissolve a deglycyrrhizinated licorice tablet in your mouth.
steps.content: Dissolve a deglycyrrhizinated licorice tablet in your mouth. Deglycyrrhizinated licorice or DGL tablets may provide some relief from canker sore pain and help to heal the tissue as well. [18] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Place one of these tablets in your mouth and allow it to dissolve right next to the canker sore. Make sure to read and follow the manufacturer’s instructions for use.

steps.title: Ask your doctor about vitamin supplements.
steps.content: Ask your doctor about vitamin supplements. Some vitamins or other dietary supplements may help heal canker sores more quickly. Although you can get these supplements over-the-counter, it’s a good idea to ask your doctor first, especially if you’re taking other medications or have any health conditions. Some supplements that may help include: [19] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source Zinc gluconate lozenges Vitamin B complex l-Lysine supplements Vitamin C

steps.title: Apply ice to canker sores to relieve pain and swelling.
steps.content: Apply ice to canker sores to relieve pain and swelling. Ice can be an effective, easy way to relieve the pain of a canker sore. To use ice on a canker sore, take an ice cube or ice chip and let it melt onto the sore. Repeat as needed. The cold will numb the area and provide some relief from the pain. [20] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Ice will also help calm any inflammation around the sore.

steps.title: Use a saltwater rinse to soothe pain and speed up healing.
steps.content: Use a saltwater rinse to soothe pain and speed up healing. To use a saltwater rinse, mix teaspoon (5 g) of salt with 1 cup (240 mL) of warm water. The salt will dissolve better in warm water. Swish the solution in your mouth and use it about 3 times per day. [21] X Research source When you’re done rinsing your mouth, spit out the salt water.

steps.title: Hold a steeped herbal tea bag on the sore.
steps.content: Hold a steeped herbal tea bag on the sore. While there’s not a lot of scientific evidence to support this treatment, some people find that a steeped herbal tea bag can relieve canker sore pain. [22] X Research source Let an herbal tea bag soak in warm water for about 5 minutes. Use just enough water to soak the tea bag. Then, remove the bag from the water and place it directly on the canker sore. Leave the tea bag in place for at least 10-15 minutes, 4 to 5 times per day. Some herbs you might find soothing include licorice root, goldenseal root, sage leaves, chamomile, peppermint, and cloves. If you don’t have tea bags, make a paste or salve by mixing a teaspoonful (about 1 g) of dried herbs with 1–2 tablespoons (15–30 mL) of coconut oil. Dab the paste directly onto the sore. Alternatively, check your pharmacy or health food store for an herbal mouthwash, such as a sage and chamomile mouthwash. [23] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Apply honey directly to the sore to promote faster healing.
steps.content: Apply honey directly to the sore to promote faster healing. Honey is soothing and has anti-inflammatory and antibiotic properties, and studies show that it can speed up the healing of mouth sores. [24] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If available, raw, organic honey is best. Apply a small amount of honey directly to the sore and allow it to dissolve. Do this 4 to 5 times per day. For the greatest medicinal benefits, get raw manuka honey. [25] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source You may be able to find this kind of honey in your local health food store or pharmacy, or you can order it online.

steps.title: Soothe your sore with a mixture of coconut and essential oils.
steps.content: Soothe your sore with a mixture of coconut and essential oils. Some essential oils, such as lavender oil, may help heal canker sores faster. [26] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Mix 3 drops of essential oil with 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of coconut oil. Apply the mixture to the canker sore using a cotton ball or a cotton swab. Alternatively, you can gargle it, but spit it out when you’re done. [27] X Research source Repeat this process 4 to 5 times per day. Choose from the following essential oils to make your mixture: Lavender Citrus [28] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Clove [29] X Research source Zataria multiflora [30] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Peppermint [31] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source While some people find that tea tree oil is effective at reducing canker sore pain, it’s poisonous if you swallow it. For this reason, it’s better to avoid using tea tree oil in your mouth. [32] X Trustworthy Source U.S. National Capital Poison Center Independent poison control center providing resources to prevent poisonings and save lives Go to source

steps.title: Practice good oral hygiene to minimize irritation.
steps.content: Practice good oral hygiene to minimize irritation. To heal and prevent canker sores, brush your teeth twice a day and try and floss each day. Make sure that you brush all tooth surfaces and use a gentle up and down stroke when brushing. Use a soft toothbrush that will not irritate your gums or mucous membranes. Finally, avoid toothpastes and mouthwashes that contain sodium lauryl sulfate, which may cause or irritate canker sores. [33] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Proper oral hygiene can also prevent new sores from forming, so make take good care of your mouth even when you don’t have a sore!

steps.title: Stick to soft, bland foods.
steps.content: Stick to soft, bland foods. It can be hard to eat when you have a painful canker sore. To minimize irritation, eat foods that are gentle and soft, such as creamy soups, yogurt, or mashed potatoes. You can also make your food easier to eat by mashing it up or blending it in a food processor.

steps.title: Minimize inflammation with cold foods and drinks.
steps.content: Minimize inflammation with cold foods and drinks. Cold fluids can numb your pain and reduce swelling and irritation. Sip cold water or other mild, non-acidic beverages, such as iced tea. Non-acidic popsicles might also help. Sometimes cold fluid can cause pain if it touches the sore directly. If this happens, try drinking through a straw.

steps.title: Steer clear of foods and beverages that may irritate your canker sore.
steps.content: Steer clear of foods and beverages that may irritate your canker sore. There are a number of foods that may make a canker sore hurt more and increase the time that it takes to heal as well. Some things that you should avoid include: [34] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Spicy foods, such as hot sauces, barbecue sauces, and peppery sauces Very hot liquids Anything you think you might have a sensitivity to, including gluten-containing products (anything with wheat in it), dairy, chocolate, coffee, strawberries, eggs, nuts, and cheese Acidic foods like citrus fruit and juices, tomatoes, and tomato sauces Oral products containing sodium lauryl sulfate
